Edgar Rice Burroughs

Tarzan of the Apes

Part of " Tarzan " series

"Tarzan of the Apes" by Edgar Rice Burroughs is a classic adventure novel that tells the story of a man who is raised by apes in the African jungle. The book, which was first published in 1912, follows the life of John Clayton, the son of British Lord and Lady Greystoke, who are marooned on the coast of Africa. After the death of his parents, the infant John is adopted by a she-ape named Kala and raised as her own. The novel explores the themes of nature versus nurture, as Tarzan, as he comes to be known, grows up with the apes, yet retains his human intelligence and curiosity. He eventually discovers his true heritage and must navigate the complexities of human society, which is vastly different from the simple life he has known in the jungle. Burroughs's vivid descriptions of the African jungle and its inhabitants, as well as his action-packed narrative, have made "Tarzan of the Apes" a beloved adventure story for generations. The character of Tarzan has been adapted into numerous films, television shows, and other forms of media, and remains a cultural icon to this day. Despite its age, "Tarzan of the Apes" remains a thrilling and engaging read, with its timeless themes and exciting storyline. It is a must-read for fans of classic adventure literature and those interested in the enduring appeal of the Tarzan mythos. In summary, "Tarzan of the Apes" is a classic adventure novel that tells the story of a man raised by apes in the African jungle, exploring themes of nature versus nurture and the complexities of human society. With its vivid descriptions, exciting narrative, and timeless themes, it remains a beloved adventure story to this day...
